zenodotus

I had to come back to get the answer to this quick question. It comes from personal curiosity.
 
 When asked if gay marriage should be allowed to exist equally with marriage, but with a different name, gay rights advocates respond that this would separate it from marriage and cause discrimination. They say the two should not be separate because there is no fundamental difference between them. The only difference is that one is man-man (or woman-woman), and the other is man-woman. Therefore, the difference is only gender related, which is a shallow dividing line.
 
 My question is that if gender is not a fundamental difference, why do we call men men and women women? Doesn't this difference in nomenclature suggest a fundamental difference between the two, and make discrimination automatic and inescapable? The two genders are similar in that both seek happiness, both extol certain virtues, both seek truth, etc. etc. So, they are different only for shallow reasons, not fundamentally, right? So should we abolish the words "male" and "female" and "boy" and "girl" etc.? Thanks.
Kronus

When asked if gay marriage should be allowed to exist equally with marriage, but with a different name, gay rights advocates respond that this would separate it from marriage and cause discrimination. They say the two should not be separate because there is no fundamental difference between them. The only difference is that one is man-man (or woman-woman), and the other is man-woman. Therefore, the difference is only gender related, which is a shallow dividing line.
 
 My question is that if gender is not a fundamental difference, why do we call men men and women women? Doesn't this difference in nomenclature suggest a fundamental difference between the two, and make discrimination automatic and inescapable? The two genders are similar in that both seek happiness, both extol certain virtues, both seek truth, etc. etc. So, they are different only for shallow reasons, not fundamentally, right? So should we abolish the words "male" and "female" and "boy" and "girl" etc.? Thanks.

 
 Quite simple. It's not that there's no difference between men and women. It's that if two people love each other, than gender shouldn't make a difference. If two consenting adults love each other and want to get married then they should be allowed to, without regards to gender. That's what's being argued, not that there isn't any difference between the genders.
joebrummer

Think of it this way.
 
 Student goes to an ivy league school and get his MD, that is what the school and society call people who have gone through this program. People respect that he is a doctor. It is universal to call him a doctor. The name is fitting to what he is.
 
 Another Student goes to a different school, and studies a program and gets his degree, but at this school when they graduate they call them a medical overseerer. It has all the same credentials, but lacks the respect. It isn't universal because not everyone recognizes this new name. It is fitting to what he is BUT......
 
 Which school would you fight to go to......
 
 The one that gets you the name people respect and recognize the meaning of
 or would you choose option two
 
 I realize this isn't a great analogy, but I still think you get the point. The word has a lot of meaning and it isn't one man one women either.

 The question is whether there is an actual difference or not. Man and woman are actually different, and so having different labels makes sense. If you create a "seperate but equal" institution that only applies to certain people, then you are in essense saying that we're going to say that you're equal, but we don't really think you are. If they were considered equal, than there would be no need for a new name. It's not the existence of labels that leads to discrimmination, it's how they're applied.

MrWriteLA

The color of an African-American's skin and that of a Caucasian can be said to be a "fundamental difference." A Muslim's religion and that of a Catholic can be said to be a "fundamental difference." The height of a person who's 6'7" is "fundamentally different" from that of someone who's 4'2". You can go on and on... a person who's blind vs. one who's not, a person who's been sentenced to life in prison vs. one who hasn't been... yet all these "fundamentally different" people are capable of loving each other and committing themselves to a life-long bond, and are capable of having that commitment recognized in the eyes of the law -- despite those who raised the "fundamental difference" argument against some of them in the past. A person's capacity for loving commitment is as unaffected by his or her gender as it is by their skin color, religion, height, vision, fertility, or any other phsical or cultural difference, no matter how great (or "fundamental") that difference may appear.

unkerpaulie

To start with, are each of the three equally devoted and committed to the other two? And the question becomes further complicated with each new person added to the mix.

 but this problem could exist even with just 2 people. its pretty much like business partnership contracts. it should be equal, but in marriages nowadays prenuptual agreements and so on are very common. it shouldnt be that hard to legally frame a 3-way marriage
sinjin

but this problem could exist even with just 2 people. its pretty much like business partnership contracts. it should be equal, but in marriages nowadays prenuptual agreements and so on are very common. it shouldnt be that hard to legally frame a 3-way marriage

 
 I don't think it impossible but that it has never been tried with respect to marriage as a true three way power split. Polygamy as practiced has never required the approval of wife number one as a condition for the husband to marry wife number two or any subsequent wives. I believe polyandrous marriages to similarly give the woman all the decision making power.
MrWriteLA

Not only that, but -- even presupposing a truly equal multispouse commitment--suppose one person of the three wants to divorce one, but not the other? And at how many participants do you draw the line? Three? Ten? Can everyone in New Jersey marry each other? These are complications that would never arise in an interracial, inter-denominational, or same-sex marriage.

If you really feel it's necessary to continue discussing multi-partner relationships I suggest you move to a new thread. Continuing to discuss this in this thread only sends a message that the "distraitionists" can continue their ploys.

I think that the question of polygamous marriages is answered cleverly in some interpretations of Islam by saying that polygamy is permitted if you can treat your partners equally - some people can love more than one person, other people can't. This is good because it allows those suited to polygamy, and by extension to polyamoury, to be polyamourous, and disallows those unsuited to it.
 
 Personally I don't see a problem with legally allowing polyamoury, the problem is rather with people knowing whether polyamoury is right for them or not. But that's their problem, and not the state's.

 What we're forgetting here, is this is about 2 consenting adults (same sex marriage) not multi partnered relationships. If some would like to see that, let them petition the courts for that right. We (GLBT) community, are trying to gain equal rights under the laws, which are currently granted to opposite sex couples and denied to us. 
 
 IMO, polygamy is a whole other issue, and would fall under a special exception law, not a civil right issue. That point seems to be brought up all to often when the issue of same sex marriage is the topic, and quite frankly, I don't understand why? 
 We're talking about marriage, not relationships shared by our society, we're talking about expanding on the genders of those marriages.
MrWriteLA

IMO, polygamy is a whole other issue, and would fall under a special exception law, not a civil right issue. That point seems to be brought up all to often when the issue of same sex marriage is the topic, and quite frankly, I don't understand why? 
 It's one in the "parade of horribles" that's supposed to come spilling out of Pandora's Box (otherwise known as legal recognition of same-sex marriages), and they revert to it again and again, regardless of the facts that:
 
 1. It is repeatedly pointed out that the "slippery slope" is a fallacy
 2. They never explain why "changing the definition of marriage" to include interracial ones didn't "open the door" to polygamy (as it was predicted it would at the time of Loving)
 3. Polygamy is still illegal and has made no in-roads in the countries/states where same-sex marriage has already been legal for some time.

sassi

Here's my theory as to why. As a friend of my suggested, once the denial of gay marriage has been proven in a court of law as being discriminatory, and a clear violation of civil rights, it becomes similar to stepping on the accelerator of a car. (Massachusetts court)
 Once case law is established, it will be hard for other States to uphold those same discriminating laws against the GLBT community that have been imposed upon us to this date. 
 Therefore, the anti side is feeling backed into a corner, and are becoming more aggressive and more apt to rely on diversion technique rather than come up compelling factual reasons to support their wanting to ban same sex marriage.

post_info.post_title: Why is the anti side so upset?

JustineCredible

Here's my theory as to why. As a friend of my suggested, once the denial of gay marriage has been proven in a court of law as being discriminatory, and a clear violation of civil rights, it becomes similar to stepping on the accelerator of a car. (Massachusetts court)
 Once case law is established, it will be hard for other States to uphold those same discriminating laws against the GLBT community that have been imposed upon us to this date. 
 Therefore, the anti side is feeling backed into a corner, and are becoming more aggressive and more apt to rely on diversion technique rather than come up compelling factual reasons to support their wanting to ban same sex marriage.

 
 Actually I wouldn't disagree at all with that. It's very similar to the civil rights fight of the 1950's and 1960's. When one group of blacks took up against the social "norm" it ignited a firestorm of backlash from the white community. 
 
 ..."how dare a little white boy from Chicago say "I'll see you later" to a white woman in Atlanta!!!???" Scandlous!! That poor innocent child was beaten beyond recognition, one eye plucked out of it's socket and then shot. His mother, after the boy's body had been transfered back to Chicago, insisted on an open casket...to make sure the world saw what happened to her son!! 
 
 How many more of our community will have to die before the laws extend to us? 
 How many more Matthew Shepard's, Barry Winchell's, Harvey Milk's, Brandon Tina's or the thousands of other gays and lesbians who are murdered simply for being gay? 
 What of the straight men and women who are murdered for the presumption that they were gay/lesbian? 
 How many of our sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, mothers, fathers, Aunts and Uncles will have to die before "All Men are created Equal" applies to EVERYONE?
sassi

 How many more Matthew Shepard's, Barry Winchell's, Harvey Milk's, Brandon Tina's or the thousands of other gays and lesbians who are murdered simply for being gay? 
 What of the straight men and women who are murdered for the presumption that they were gay/lesbian? 
 How many of our sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, mothers, fathers, Aunts and Uncles will have to die before "All Men are created Equal" applies to EVERYONE?[/QUOTE]

 The problem is that, on one hand, you want to redefine marriage from its traditional man/woman to a broader, man.woman, man/man, woman/woman, but you want to gloss over the belief that allowing the redefinition of marriage away from the traditional man/woman opens the door to other possible definitions.
 While it serves your interests to ONLY talk about 2-person relationships, once marriage is redefined, the precedence is set to broaden the definition even further and this is something that doesn't fit in the gay agenda. By exposing the risks in redefining marriage, gays will lose support for their cause so steering the debate away from polygamy is in their best interests.
 I believe that any debate on the redefinition of marriage has to include possible unforeseen consequences of the action. Polygamy is one of the more predictable potential consequences.

Nurglitch

And yet they "redefine" marriage differently. Polygamy is about the number of wives that a man can have, and same-sex marriage is about the sex of the partners in a marriage. 
 
 So saying that they're both about "redefining marriage" is like saying that apples and oranges are both fruit. Correct, but missing the point when you're trying to decide whether to allow only granny-smith apples or both granny-smith apples and golden-delicious apples.
JakeCJB

The problem is that, on one hand, you want to redefine marriage from its traditional man/woman to a broader, man.woman, man/man, woman/woman, but you want to gloss over the belief that allowing the redefinition of marriage away from the traditional man/woman opens the door to other possible definitions.

 
 Traditional was polygamy. It was re-defined to not allow polygamy. It was redefined to allow for different races, religions, no religion, legal divorce. Draw the line for me as to how re-defining it this time to allow for same-sex couples, leads to polygamy. You can't.
 
 
While it serves your interests to ONLY talk about 2-person relationships, once marriage is redefined, the precedence is set to broaden the definition even further

 
 If the precedence was set, it was set long before legal same-sex marriage. You can't say how same-sex marriage specifically, is a precedent.
 
 
and this is something that doesn't fit in the gay agenda.

 
 Correct.
 
 
By exposing the risks in redefining marriage, gays will lose support for their cause

 
 And the only way you can fight same-sex marriage is by arguing about polygamy? What if we argued we can't have polygamy because that will risk us allowing for two same-sex persons to marry? Isn't that ridiculous? I think you will rapidly start to lose support for your cause. It's built on thin, soft, grains of sand, and the tide of reason is coming in to sweep it away. 
 
 
so steering the debate away from polygamy is in their best interests.

 
 It doesn't make our interests wrong, and polygamy is not our interest.
 
 
I believe that any debate on the redefinition of marriage has to include possible unforeseen consequences of the action. Polygamy is one of the more predictable potential consequences.

 
 How in the heck is polygamy a predictable consequence of same-sex marriage? You haven't proven that.
JakeCJB

And yet they "redefine" marriage differently. Polygamy is about the number of wives that a man can have, and same-sex marriage is about the sex of the partners in a marriage. 
 
 So saying that they're both about "redefining marriage" is like saying that apples and oranges are both fruit. Correct, but missing the point when you're trying to decide whether to allow only granny-smith apples or both granny-smith apples and golden-delicious apples.

 
 Bingo. Opponents of same-sex marriage are being too broad.
JPSartre12

And yet they "redefine" marriage differently. Polygamy is about the number of wives that a man can have, and same-sex marriage is about the sex of the partners in a marriage. 
 
 So saying that they're both about "redefining marriage" is like saying that apples and oranges are both fruit. Correct, but missing the point when you're trying to decide whether to allow only granny-smith apples or both granny-smith apples and golden-delicious apples.

 
 You're arbitrarily making a distinction that can as easily be argued the other way. The natural order of things in the animal world is male/female, be it one dominant male and several females or one male/one female. Your redefinition of marriage bucks the natural order and is therefore, IMO, even a more radical departure.
JakeCJB

You're arbitrarily making a distinction that can as easily be argued the other way. The natural order of things in the animal world is male/female, be it one dominant male and several females or one male/one female. Your redefinition of marriage bucks the natural order and is therefore, IMO, even a more radical departure.

 
 Well, then it's a departure in the other direction away from polygamy, like I said earlier.
Nurglitch

You're arbitrarily making a distinction that can as easily be argued the other way. The natural order of things in the animal world is male/female, be it one dominant male and several females or one male/one female. Your redefinition of marriage bucks the natural order and is therefore, IMO, even a more radical departure.
I'm afraid I don't follow you. I'm talking about how polygamy and same-sex marriage relate to marriage. What are you talking about?
JPSartre12

Well, then it's a departure in the other direction away from polygamy, like I said earlier.

 
 It's a departure in the other direction from normalcy. Polygamy is still heterosexual.
JPSartre12

I'm afraid I don't follow you. I'm talking about how polygamy and same-sex marriage relate to marriage. What are you talking about?

 
 My point is that comparing polygamy and homosexuality is comparing apples to oranges, not varieties of apples to themselves.
JakeCJB

It's a departure in the other direction from normalcy.

 
 In terms of the sex make-up, but still a couple. Is polygamy "normalcy", in your view?
 
 
Polygamy is still heterosexual.

 
 
My point is that comparing polygamy and homosexuality is comparing apples to oranges, not varieties of apples to themselves.

 
 At any rate, you are saying that polygamy has no connection to homosexuality. It is heterosexual. So what is the connection to gay marriage, if you believe there is one?
